awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Magnetic Nanostructures with Perpendicular Anisotropy
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

A key attribute of a magnetic material is the ability to retain its magnetic moment in certain directions, or magnetic anisotropy. For example, an iron needle is usually magnetized along its long axis and a thin iron foil would have its moments lying in the film plane. Certain nanoscale magnets in thin film forms, however, prefer to orient their moments perpendicular to the films - known as perpendicular magnetic anisotropy. Such nanomagnets are technologically important, as they allow much more efficient information storage at higher densities, analogous to the benefits of building skyscrapers with small real-estate footprints.  This project investigates two types of such nanomaterials that have potentially transformative technological impacts: 1. ordered alloys of iron/platinum-based materials as storage media in next generation ultrahigh density magnetic recording; 2. a novel type of nanomagnet arrays where the magnetic moments take up a special arrangement known as the skyrmion state. The magnetic skyrmions offer potentially new mechanisms for information storage that is not only robust, but also highly energy efficient, expected to be at a tiny fraction of the energy cost of current technologies. Students involved will receive exposure to research experiences in university, national laboratory and user-facility, and industrial research and development. 


Technical Abstract

Alloys of FePt-based materials in the ordered phase are promising media choices for the emerging heat-assisted magnetic recording technology due to their high anisotropy, large saturation magnetization, and moderate Curie temperature. This project addresses critical challenges in the convenient realization of the high anisotropy phase, and understanding and control over the switching field distribution. Thin films of FePt-based alloys in the ordered phase are investigated. Basic understanding and control of the magnetization reversal are gained through magnetometry and first-order reversal curve studies at elevated temperatures. The second research area focuses on magnetic skyrmions that exhibit topologically protected quantum states and other unique topological phenomena. Hybrid skyrmion lattices based on perpendicular anisotropy films are synthesized and investigated to demonstrate the ground state at room temperature. A set of magnetic field sequences is followed to establish the skyrmion lattices, as well as vortex lattices and mixed lattices for comparison. Magnetic imaging, polarized neutron reflectometry, magneto-transport studies, and micromagnetic simulations are carried out to probe the skyrmions and their responses to external stimuli. These artificial skyrmions are expected to be stable over wide temperature and field ranges, thus offering an exciting platform to explore the intriguing physics in such exotic spin textures.

por.por_cntn:
Nanostructures with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) prefer to have their magnetic moments aligned normal to the sample plane. They exhibit fascinating magnetization reversal mechanisms and are technologically important. For example, magnetic skyrmions may be achieved at room temperature in PMA thin films; high perpendicular anisotropy L10 FePt based alloys have critical applications in the emerging heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) media. This project focuses on such PMA materials to understand the underlying physics and to explore their potential applications.

Intellectual Merit

A variety of magnetic nanostructures with PMA have been realized. Depth-dependent magnetization profiles, magnetic interactions and magnetization reversal characteristics have been investigated. Major results include the following:

1. We have achieved a variety of artificial Bloch-type skyrmion lattices stable at ambient conditions, using hybrid structures combining the spin texture of in-plane magnetic vortices with a PMA film. They form periodic arrays of particle-like winding magnetic configurations, where the magnetic moments follow certain topological patterns, in a way analogous to the wind pattern in a hurricane. Such configurations are promising for information storage with extremely low energy dissipation. The existence of these skyrmions are verified using a combination of magnetometry, magnetic imaging, neutron scattering, electrical-transport measurements, and confirmed by simulations.

2. We have demonstrated an extremely sensitive magnetic yoking effect and continuous tuning of interactions in a model system consisting of a magnetically hard FePt layer in the L10 phase with PMA, and a magnetically soft FePt layer in the A1 phase with a varying thickness. By tailoring the soft layer thickness by just a few nanometers, across the exchange length, the soft layer magnetization turns in-plane to facilitate the dipolar interaction across neighboring L10-FePt domains with perpendicular magnetization. As a result, the dominant interaction in the bilayer system can be continuously and sensitively tuned from exchange to dipolar.

3. We have demonstrated an effective control mechanism of metal/oxide interfaces through oxygen migration, which has been difficult to observe directly since the ionic transport occur underneath buried interfaces. Utilizing the strong oxygen affinity of gadolinium, we design a model system of GdFe/NiCoO bilayer films, where the oxygen migration is observed and manifested in a shift of the hysteresis loop known as exchange bias. We further show that the coupling between the layers moderated by voltage-driven oxygen migration extends well beyond the interface region in relatively thick films. This is in contrast to prior studies, where the most prominent effect demonstrated so far is the modification of the interface only.

4. We have use the first-order reversal curve (FORC) method to magnetically "fingerprint" the coupling behavior of CoFe grown on epitaxial BiFeO3 thin films, which is often manifested in the exchange bias effect. The contribution to exchange bias from various ferroelectric domain walls was elucidated by the FORC distribution.

This project has so far led to 7 publications in top journals in the field, including 2 papers in Nature Communications, 1 in Scientific Reports, 3 in Applied Physics Letters, 1 in IEEE Magnetics Letters, and a few more submitted manuscripts. The results have been presented in over 20 invited talks at conferences and various research institutes in 2016.

Broader Impacts

Results from this project have potentially important and broad technological impacts. Our studies on magnetic skyrmions and magneto-ionics represent two promising approaches for low power nanoelectronics of the future: in magnetic skyrmions, the topologically protected quantum states offer exciting new mechanisms for low dissipation information storage; in magneto-ionic control of metal/oxide heterostructures, ionic motion is shown to be highly effective in tailoring the interfacial characteristics. Our two 2016 Nature Communications papers on the latter topic have been featured by U. C. Davis Science Blog and MRS Bulletin, respectively. Furthermore, our studies on L10 FePt have direct impacts in magnetic recording, as the tunable exchange vs. dipolar interactions via the yoking effect can be used to control the media switching field distribution.

This project has contributed to the development of several junior researchers. They received valuable exposure to research at national laboratories (National Institute of Standards and Technology, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory), and several international research institutes in Taiwan, Germany, Spain, China, UK, France, and Sweden. These junior researchers had regular and extensive discussions about their results and interpretations with the PI. They also received training on scientific writing and presentation skills from their research activities. They presented their work at many conferences, including delivering several invited talks on PI’s behalf. Student recognitions include selection by the IEEE Magnetics Society to participate in its 2016 Summer School in Sendai, Japan, selection by NIST to participate in its 2016 Neutron Scattering Summer School, and selection by U.C. Davis as recipient of a 2016 Summer Graduate Student Researcher Award.
